carousel_items: This is one of the few drugs where the brand really does work better than the generic for some people.

Food prevents Levothyroxine absorption. Take it on an empty stomach with a full glass of water at least 30 minutes before breakfast and other medicines. If this is too much of a hassle for you and you end up skipping your medicine, it's better to just take it whenever you want, and your doctor can increase the dose if needed.
Separate by at least 4 hours from any antacids, calcium or iron supplements, and multivitamins.
Starts working in 1 to 2 weeks. Full effects in 6 to 8 weeks.
Can cause irregular heart rate, anxiety, sweating, or trouble sleeping until your body gets used to the medicine. Side effects might not go away if the dose is too high for you.
Not all generics and brands are the same. Double-check with your pharmacist that you have the right medicine for you.

clock.tip: Works quicker when taken without food.

basics.benefits_moa: Levothyroxine is a synthetic version of a hormone made by your thyroid gland. Thyroid hormones affect many important bodily functions, like controlling metabolism and telling your body how to use energy sources.
basics.bottom_line: Levothyroxine is an important replacement hormone when your body can't make enough thyroid hormone. It's easily affected by food, other medicines or supplements, and health conditions, so you should try to take it exactly as instructed.
downsides: Absorption is easily affected by food and other medicines.
Not one-dose-fits-all: Dose adjustments are usually needed when starting the medicine and when your health changes.
Routine blood tests are needed at least yearly and more during dose adjustments, but it takes a long time to see full effect (6 to 8 weeks).

Different brands of Levothyroxine may not work the same. Ask your pharmacist if your refill looks different than your old pills. Synthroid is one of the few drugs where the brand really does work better than the generic for many people.
Lots of drug interactions, so check with your pharmacist before taking anything new.

downsides_processed.orig: Absorption is easily affected by food and other medicines.

Routine blood tests are needed at least yearly and more during dose adjustments, but it takes a long time to see full effect (6 to 8 weeks).

Different brands of Levothyroxine may not work the same. Ask your pharmacist if your refill looks different than your old pills. Synthroid is one of the few drugs where the brand really does work better than the generic for many people.
Lots of drug interactions, so check with your pharmacist before taking anything new.

upsides: Supplies an essential hormone that your body needs to function. Works well to improve symptoms of an underactive thyroid.
Safe to use for any age range and pregnant women.

upsides_processed.orig: Supplies an essential hormone that your body needs to function. Works well to improve symptoms of an underactive thyroid.
Safe to use for any age range and pregnant women.

userStories.tip: Take it every single day!
Most important....a good endocrinologist.  Mine got the right medicine at the right dosage from the start.  Manages adjustments as needed. Never had problems.
I take if very early in AM before getting out of bed.  I put one pill on top of the bottle the night before so there's no problems that early in day and I've never missed a dose..

userStories.identifier: Mom, works full time and is hypothyroid.
userStories.tip: I had tremendous anxiety for 48 hours before my period.  I could not concentrate was afraid to drive and could not work.  After 2 months I demanded a change to Armour.

userStories.identifier: I am a 74 year old female
userStories.tip: After many years of taking 50 mcg. daily of this drug, I developed a severe allergic reaction.  I actually felt so ill that I thought that I had a terminal illness and was going to die.  Very bad stuff!  I don't know if they changed the fillers or formula as they have in the past.  There have been reports of problems when that occurred.  All I know is I will never, ever take Synthroid or similar drugs again.  Who wants to have flaking, inflamed eyelids, shortness of breath and problems with joints and muscles.  Couple this with overwhelming fatigue and you have a recipe for disaster.
Get an adjustment in dosage after you start.
It's not a joke. It's important you don't forget to take it. No taking it as you should can have serious effects on you.

The generic worked fine for me for probably 8 years but the last 2 have been awful -- terrible weight gain, depression, constipation. Blood work shows it's working just right but clearly something is wrong.
It takes time to take effect & the weight gained because of a slow thyroid did not just fall off-took me 5 years to lose.
Thinning of hair , brittle nails
Calcium and fiber restrictions need to be addressed when Rx is given. I found out how it impacts absorption through my own research.

The generic version of this medicine did not work at all, I switched to the brand name and it works better for me. I also started taking mine at night and have found the absorption and effectiveness increased significantly.
There is a big difference between the generic and brand name medication

userStories.identifier: 47 yr old Female thyroid issues for 30 y

userStories.tip: Be careful when your doctor adjusts your dosages. A tiny change can make a *huge* difference. Don't let them change your levels too quickly.

userStories.satisfaction: Not worth it, thinking about stopping
userStories.tip: I had to take the generic form of the medication in order to show how it did not work for me. I felt horrible on this medication, lethargic, depressed, it was a challenge. Just didn't work for me. I am one of the few who needs brand name.
I would give up a meal in order to get my prescription filled - effects of hypothyroid condition too miserable to consider doing without this drug.
If you are taking it while pregnant get tested monthly, even in the last stages of pregnancy, and make sure all results are sent to your specialist.
Talk to your doctor if you still feel sluggish at your dose. It took me a while to get mine right, but I have been ok and weight-stable etc for years now.
My asymptomatic Hashimoto's (hypothyroidism) was diagnosed while troubleshooting fertility problems.  I got pregnant immediately after I started taking levothyroxine.
My asymptomatic Hashimoto's (hypothyroidism) was diagnosed while troubleshooting fertility problems.  I got pregnant immediately after I started taking levothyroxine.

Having to take it early, before  coffee or breakfast, is inconvenient, but totally worth it when you get your energy back. Also, I found that it didn't work nearly as well for me till I started regulating my blood sugar through better diet choices.  I don't feel hypo any more!
userStories.identifier: Young, educated mom of 3 active kids

userStories.satisfaction: Not worth it, thinking about stopping
userStories.tip: I dont feel any different, only my blood results shows its impact
If you're pregnant your dose will most likely increase so make sure to meet with your endo monthly
No issues, would prefer not to take. But not an option.

drugs.name: Synthroid

Food prevents Levothyroxine absorption. Take it on an empty stomach with a full glass of water at least 30 minutes before breakfast and other medicines. If this is too much of a hassle for you and you end up skipping your medicine, it's better to just take it whenever you want, and your doctor can increase the dose if needed.
Separate by at least 4 hours from any antacids, calcium or iron supplements, and multivitamins.
Starts working in 1 to 2 weeks. Full effects in 6 to 8 weeks.
Can cause irregular heart rate, anxiety, sweating, or trouble sleeping until your body gets used to the medicine. Side effects might not go away if the dose is too high for you.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Levothyroxine can cause new or worsen heart problems. Call your doctor or get medical care right away if you have rapid or irregular heartbeats, chest pain or shortness of breath. These symptoms may be serious and due to overtreatment of Levothyroxine. You may need to stop taking your medicine for one week, then re-start at a lower dose.
risk_factors: Taking Levothyroxine with certain types of stimulant medicines

description_processed.orig: Taking Levothyroxine can cause new or worsen heart problems. Call your doctor or get medical care right away if you have rapid or irregular heartbeats, chest pain or shortness of breath. These symptoms may be serious and due to overtreatment of Levothyroxine. You may need to stop taking your medicine for one week, then re-start at a lower dose.

risks_warnings.title: Weight reduction
risks_warnings.description: don't take Levothyroxine for weight loss or obesity.  It’s not recommended, safe or effective for this use, especially if you don't have any issues with your thyroid. Taking high doses of Levothyroxine can cause serious or fatal effects especially if used with other medications for weight loss.  Talk to your doctor before about other medicines you can take to treat your condition.

Taking high doses of Levothyroxine can cause serious or fatal effects especially if used with other medications for weight loss.  Talk to your doctor before about other medicines you can take to treat your condition.

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: Many medicines interact with Levothyroxine. You may need your dose adjusted, especially if they are "narrow" therapy medicines like warfarin. Let your doctor and pharmacist know if you are taking any new prescriptions or over-the-counter medicines.

description_processed.orig: Many medicines interact with Levothyroxine. You may need your dose adjusted, especially if they are "narrow" therapy medicines like warfarin. Let your doctor and pharmacist know if you are taking any new prescriptions or over-the-counter medicines.

risks_warnings.title: Bone effects
risks_warnings.description: Levothyroxine can thin the bones. Using the lowest possible dose to treat your condition will reduce this risk.

description_processed.orig: Levothyroxine can thin the bones. Using the lowest possible dose to treat your condition will reduce this risk.

risks_warnings.title: Lack of adrenal function
risks_warnings.description: Low thyroid can be the result of other hormonal conditions. Autoimmune thyroid disease, low hypothalamus/adrenal function, type-1 diabetes, and pernicious anemia, from vitamin B12 deficiency. If you have an adrenal condition, your doctor will decide if you need to be treated for other conditions before taking Levothyroxine.

If you have an adrenal condition, your doctor will decide if you need to be treated for other conditions before taking Levothyroxine.
